results.title: Planning and goal setting: time waste or management tool
results.creator_credit: Pare Lorentz Jr, Fred H Joiner, Ameron and BNA Communications
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Manager and the Organization”.
Explores the advantages and disadvantages of economic forecasts and business plans, various practicalities and difficulties to overcome and how to overcome them. Also considers the costs and benefits of planning yourself, or out-sourcing professional planners.

results.title: Seeds of destruction
results.creator_credit: George E. Brewer Jnr, The Conservation Foundation and New York Zoological Society
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Living Earth”.

This film illustrates what happens when any one of the vital links in the “chain of life” is broken. Unscientific lumbering practices, devastating forest fires, uncontrolled wind and water erosion, overworked land, and roaring floods are shown as the agents which can destroy the world unless humans begin to act to combat the havoc caused by thoughtless use of natural resources.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George E. Brewer Jnr, The Conservation Foundation and New York Zoological Society

results.title: This vital earth
results.creator_credit: George E. Brewer Jnr, New York Zoological Society and The Conservation Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Living Earth”
The relation of life to its environment is shown through the balance of plants and animals. The film shows that plant and animal inter-relationships are essential for the survival of both.

results.title: Birth of the soil
results.creator_credit: George E. Brewer Jnr and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Living Earth”.
This film shows how nature produces life-giving topsoil from the basic raw materials of rock, air, and sunlight, by the processes of plant growth and decay and photosynthesis.

results.title: Arteries of life
results.creator_credit: George E. Brewer Jnr and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Living Earth”.
Water and forests are shown as important elements in the “chain of life”. It is demonstrated that topsoil is helpless in supplying and sustaining life unless aided by water, and that water itself depends on forests which provide humus in the soil to store and regulate the flow of water.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George E. Brewer Jnr and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films

results.title: The Living Cell
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

group_works.title: The Role of the cell membrane

results.title: What are cells?
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Living Cell”.
To introduce this film the concept of cellular organization of plants and animals is examined and the main parts of a cell are identified. The diversity of cells within a single organism is illustrated. A brief history of microscopy shows how improvements in instrument made possible the formulation of the cell theory. An animated sequence demonstrates the process of mitotic nuclear division in an animal cell and the film end s by showing the major differences between plant and animals cells.

group_siblings.title: The Role of the cell membrane
group_siblings.creator_credit: Statens Film Central

results.title: The Role of the cell membrane
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Living Cell”.
Uses close-up photomicrography of a series of amoeba to show the structure and role of the cell membrane, or plasmalemma, as it pertains to “phagocytosis” and “pinocytosis”. Also shows an experiment investigating active transport of sodium ions across live frog skin and discusses possible mechanism for this behaviour. No other credits available.
